results.title: Pottery without a wheel. Parts. 1-3
results.creator_credit: Richard Philps and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Potter: a series of films”.
The use of clay for the formation of useful objects such as tiles, trays and pots is discussed and demonstrated in this video which is specifically aimed at junior grades. Most of the examples are made with the assistance of students. These are treated in sequential order and degree of difficulty: Pottery without a wheel Part 1 - the use of coil pots are shown and made, the movement and rolling of clay as with the tools which are used for shaping and finishing are discussed. Pottery without a wheel Part 2 - the techniques of firing and finishing of the pots are shown. The making of tiles and other rolled objects are shown. Pottery without a wheel Part 3 - This discusses the firing and glazing of the finished pots and clay objects.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Philps and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids

results.title: Pottery without a wheel. Part 3. Slab work and coiled work
results.creator_credit: Richard Philps and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description: Three methods of making pots without a wheel. The third method demonstrates coiled work. A coiled-work bowl is made and other articles are shown.

results.title: Pottery without a wheel
results.brief_description: The best clay for pottery making is secured in Cornwall. Film shows how clay is prepared and how a thumb pot is made. Also demonstrates how to make a pot or model by the coil method, and how to make tiles and the various methods of decorating then with slip.
results.description: The best clay for pottery making is secured in Cornwall. Film shows how clay is prepared and how a thumb pot is made. Also demonstrates how to make a pot or model by the coil method, and how to make tiles and the various methods of decorating then with slip.

results.title: Pottery making
results.brief_description: Shows professional potter at work mixing clay, centring it on the wheel, shaping, trimming and preparing it for firing. The making of the plaster casts and glazing are also studied.

results.title: Pottery ladies. Part 4
results.creator_credit: Jenny Wilkes, Elizabeth Taylor-Mead and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Focuses on Susie Cooper and the women employed to manufacture pottery under her direction. Offers an insight into design techniques and production from an economic perspective and examines the impact of war and post war economics on designers and the pottery industry. Interviews with Susie Cooper, Gordon Elliot, Ann Eatwell (Victoria and Albert Museum) and Peggy Davies.

results.title: Pottery ladies. Part 3
results.creator_credit: Jenny Wilkes, Elizabeth Taylor-Mead and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Insight into the techniques and working conditions of the women employed to manufacture “Clarice Cliff” pottery under her direction. The influence of these women on Cliff’s career. Interviews with Gordon Elliot (historian), Susie Cooper (designer), Peggy Davies (sculptor) and Ethel Cliff.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jenny Wilkes, Elizabeth Taylor-Mead and Arts Council of Great Britain

results.title: Pottery ladies. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Jenny Wilkes, Elizabeth Taylor-Mead and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Colin Melbourne (former head of Burslem Art School), Peggy Davies (pottery sculptor) and Gordon Elliot (ceramic historian) discuss the relationship between the Burslem Art School and the pottery industry and the influences on the works of the designers Susie Cooper, Charlotte Rhead and Clarice Cliff.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jenny Wilkes, Elizabeth Taylor-Mead and Arts Council of Great Britain

results.title: Pottery ladies. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Jenny Wilkes, Elizabeth Taylor-Mead and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Joan Jackson (Rhead’s biographer), Gordon Elliot (ceramic historian), Barry Leigh (manufacturer) and the women employed in the manufacturing process of Rhead’s work discuss and trace the history, influences and production techniques of Charlotte Rhead’s work.

results.title: Potters of Hebron
results.brief_description: Looks at a Middle Eastern family of potters who make water pitchers and other utensils for local consumption. The traditional techniques shown include finding the source of clay, preparation, wedging, throwing, firing and the kick wheel.
results.description: Looks at a Middle Eastern family of potters who make water pitchers and other utensils for local consumption. The traditional techniques shown include finding the source of clay, preparation, wedging, throwing, firing and the kick wheel.
